newsitem.title: CHINA: Summer rains slake China capital's thirst.
newsitem.headline: Summer rains slake China capital's thirst.

text.p: Heavy summer rains have ended a drought in the Chinese capital Beijing and have raised underground water levels in surrounding areas by more than a metre (three ft), the Xinhua news agency said on Thursday.
Frequent downpours over the past three months had ensured the city an ample supply of water for at least two years, the agency quoted an official water survey as saying.

As much as 3.89 billion cubic metres (137 billion cu ft) of water had been stored in 16 large reservoirs around the city, a rise of 350 million cu metres (12.36 billion cu ft) compared with last year, it said but gave no details.
The capital's water managers had moved some reservoir water underground, adding to the rise in water levels, it said.
Beijing, like many areas in northern China, has for years suffered water shortages caused by dry weather and spiralling demand for water for irrigation, industry and growing urban populations.
Beijing officials have said the capital's water deficit is expected to hit 1.0 billion cu metres (35 billion cu ft) a year by the year 2010.
